body_html:
I would guess it has less to do with the operation and more to do with the size of the tensor.

On my machine a.size() causes an overflow error stating OverflowError: Python int too large to convert to C long, but a.numpy().shape works correctly. I still get the overflow error when using different tensor types. Using ByteTensor to define a only uses ~3GB of memory compared to ~22GB, but still throws the same error. And if I set size=1000*1000*1000, then a.size() starts working again for both ByteTensor and LongTensor.

body:
I would guess it has less to do with the operation and more to do with the size of the tensor. 

On my machine `a.size()` causes an overflow error stating `OverflowError: Python int too large to convert to C long`, but `a.numpy().shape` works correctly. I still get the overflow error when using different tensor types. Using `ByteTensor` to define `a` only uses ~3GB of memory compared to ~22GB, but still throws the same error. And if I set `size=1000*1000*1000`, then `a.size()` starts working again for both `ByteTensor` and `LongTensor`.
